Here's the rephrased text with the noisy text removed:

The study retrieved 39 years of sea ice data from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) and atmospheric and oceanic variables from the ERA5 reanalysis product. The results show that our multi-temporal ensemble method outperforms several baseline and recently proposed deep learning models. This improvement will significantly enhance our ability to predict future Arctic sea ice changes, which is crucial for forecasting transportation routes, resource development, coastal erosion, threats to Arctic coastal communities, and wildlife.

Introduction:

Over the past three decades, the Arctic sea ice has been warming at a rate almost twice as fast as the rest of the world. This phenomenon is known as Arctic amplification (Holland & Bitz, 2003). This amplification will further alter climate patterns beyond the Arctic region, leading to more intense and frequent extreme weather events. A recent example is the 2021 cold snap in Texas and Oklahoma, where over 3,000 daily low temperature records were broken, resulting in at least 176 fatalities and $195 billion in economic losses (Freedman et al., 2021).

The sea ice plays a vital role in the Arctic climate system and has declined by half since 1979, when satellite observations became available (Serreze & Stroeve, 2015). Current trends suggest that the Arctic ocean could be ice-free by 2050 (Notz & Stroeve, 2018). This rapid change has significant local and global impacts on transportation routes, resource development, coastal erosion, military and civilian infrastructure, Arctic coastal communities (including indigenous populations' hunting and transportation), and wildlife (e.g., polar bear access to food sources).

While most scientists agree that this rapid Arctic warming is a sign of human-caused climate change, studying the causes of Arctic amplification and forecasting sea ice has become a highly debated topic in Earth Science research (Holland et al., 2019). Current operational sea ice forecasting systems rely on coupled Earth System Models, which estimate the solution to differential equations of fluid motion and thermodynamics to obtain time and space-dependent values for various variables in the atmosphere, ocean, or sea ice. However, these physics-based models perform no better than simple statistical methods at lead times of two months and beyond.

In recent years, there have been many studies focusing on sea ice forecasting using data-driven Artificial Intelligence (AI) approaches like machine learning and deep learning. Chi & Kim (2017) compared the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model with a traditional statistical model and found that the LSTM showed good performance for 1-month sea ice concentration (SIC) prediction, with less than 9% average monthly errors. However, there was lower predictability during the melting season, with a root-mean-squared-error (RMSE) of 11.09% from July to September.

Wang et al. (2017) showed the superiority of the convolutional neural networks (CNN) in SIC prediction with an estimated RMSE of 22% compared to a multi-layer perceptron model. Kim et al. (2019) applied deep neural networks with Bayesian model averaging ensemble to predict the SIC in the next 10 to 20 years and found an annual RMSE of 19.4%. More recently, Kim et al. (2020) built a novel 1-month SIC prediction model with CNNs using eight predictors to predict SIC both temporally and spatially. They showed that CNNs had better performance than a random forest model and the persistence model based on the monthly trend, with an RMSE of 5.76%.

Liu et al. (2021) proposed a 1-day SIC prediction model based on the Convolutional LSTM and concluded that the predictability of Convolutional LSTM always performed better than that of the CNN, with an RMSE of 11.24% through 10 consecutive days of iterative prediction.

In light of the above related work, we introduce a sea ice forecasting system with Attention-based Ensemble Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to predict monthly sea ice extent with a lead time of 1 month. The primary goal of this study is to develop deep learning-based forecasting models that can utilize multi-temporal data to forecast daily, weekly, and monthly sea-ice extent with high accuracy.

Our major contributions are as follows:

* We propose an ensembling method for multi-temporal Deep Learning models that performs ensembling of constituent models to improve forecasting accuracy.
* We develop an Attention-based Ensemble LSTM network to predict monthly sea ice extent with a lead time of 1 month.
* We demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method in improving forecasting accuracy compared to existing deep learning models.
